title: Vanguard Way Walking Route

images.title: Nigel Freeman / Stile on Vanguard Way
images.caption: Stile on Vanguard Way. Looking south towards the Mill House and pond where the Wealdway meets the Vanguard Way. The small stream known as Tickerage feeds the pond.

images.title: David Kemp / Vanguard Way footpath
images.caption: Taken from the footbridge over an un-named stream south of Hammerwood. Photo taken in the spring of 2008.

images.title: Nigel Freeman / Vanguard Way
images.caption: Looking south after leaving Pound Lane, the Vanguard Way path crosses open fields then down to the Tickeridge stream.

images.title: David Kemp / View from the Vanguard Way footpath
images.caption: The footpath and the trees in the foreground are all within the gridsquare. The high ground on the horizon is part of the Ashdown Forest.

images.title: Simon Carey / Vanguard Way/Ouse Valley Walk
images.caption: Looking toward a junction of embankments with the two long distance footpaths heading to the left towards Tide Mills and Newhaven where the Vanguard Way ends after travelling down from Croydon and the Ouse Valley Way really only begins (if heading upstream) on its 42 mile journey to Lower Beeding.

images.title: Simon Carey / Vanguard Way
images.caption: The long distance footpath follows the course of the bridleway from Berwick before turning south down the drive to Stonery Farm which is behind the hedge to the right.

images.title: Simon Carey / Vanguard Way
images.caption: The route includes the cliff top walk from Seaford to Cuckmere Haven. This area includes the Seaford Head Nature Reserve which includes a variety of flora and fauna with some spectacular views of the Cuckmere valley.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Vanguard Way near Gills Lap in Ashdown Forest

description: This 66 mile trail runs from the outskirts of London, through Ashdown Forest, Alfriston and Cuckmere Valley to the stunning East Sussex coast. Route highlights include the lovely Ashdown Forest, the White Horse near Alfriston and the wonderful final coastal stretch that gives views of the Seven Sisters Cliffs and Tidemills beach. The path also passes through the beautiful Cuckmere Valley with splendid views of Cuckmere River and Cuckmere Haven to enjoy. Please click here for more information.
